channel.title: TIL: Today I learned... on Yanir Seroussi – AI/ML Engineering Consultant
channel.description: Recent content in TIL: Today I learned... on Yanir Seroussi – AI/ML Engineering Consultant
channel.copyright: Text and figures licensed under CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 by Yanir Seroussi, except where noted otherwise

item.title: Five team-building mistakes, according to Patty McCord
item.description: Takeaways from an interview with Patty McCord on The Startup Podcast.

item.title: Dealing with endless data changes
item.description: Quotes from Demetrios Brinkmann on the relationship between MLOps and DevOps, with MLOps allowing for managing changes that come from data.

item.title: The rules of the passion economy
item.description: Summary of the main messages from the book The Passion Economy by Adam Davidson.

item.title: Adapting to the economy of algorithms
item.description: Overview of the book The Economy of Algorithms by Marek Kowalkiewicz.

item.title: LinkedIn is a teachable skill
item.description: An high-level overview of things I learned from Justin Welsh’s LinkedIn Operating System course.

item.title: The data engineering lifecycle is not going anywhere
item.description: My key takeaways from reading Fundamentals of Data Engineering by Joe Reis and Matt Housley.

item.title: Atomic Habits is full of actionable advice
item.description: I put the book to use after the first listen, and will definitely revisit it in the future to form better habits.

item.title: The three Cs of indie consulting: Confidence, Cash, and Connections
item.description: Jonathan Stark makes a compelling argument why you should have the three Cs before quitting your job to go solo consulting.

item.title: Future software development may require fewer humans
item.description: Reflecting on an interview with Jason Warner, CEO of poolside.

item.title: Psychographic specialisations may work for discipline generalists
item.description: When focusing on a market segment defined by personal beliefs, it’s often fine to position yourself as a generalist in your craft.

item.title: The power of parasocial relationships
item.description: Repeated exposure to media personas creates relationships that help justify premium fees.

item.title: Positioning is a common problem for data scientists
item.description: With the commodification of data scientists, the problem of positioning has become more common: My takeaways from Genevieve Hayes interviewing Jonathan Stark.

item.title: Transfer learning applies to energy market bidding
item.description: An interesting approach to bidding of energy storage assets, showing that training on New York data is transferable to Queensland.

item.title: Our Blue Machine is changing, but we are not helpless
item.description: One of my many highlights from Helen Czerski’s Blue Machine.

item.title: You don't need a proprietary API for static maps
item.description: For many use cases, libraries like cartopy are better than the likes of Mapbox and Google Maps.

item.title: Artificial intelligence was a marketing term all along – just call it automation
item.description: Replacing ‘artificial intelligence’ with ‘automation’ is a useful trick for cutting through the hype.

item.title: The lines between solo consulting and product building are blurry
item.description: It turns out that problems like finding a niche and defining the ideal clients are key to any solo business.

item.title: Google's Rules of Machine Learning still apply in the age of large language models
item.description: Despite the excitement around large language models, building with machine learning remains an engineering problem with established best practices.

item.title: The Minimalist Entrepreneur is too prescriptive for me
item.description: While I found the story of Gumroad interesting, The Minimalist Entrepreneur seems to over-generalise from the founder’s experience.

item.title: Revisiting Start Small, Stay Small in 2023 (Chapter 2)
item.description: A summary of the second chapter of Rob Walling’s Start Small, Stay Small, along with my thoughts & reflections.

item.title: Revisiting Start Small, Stay Small in 2023 (Chapter 1)
item.description: A summary of the first chapter of Rob Walling’s Start Small, Stay Small, along with my thoughts & reflections.

item.title: Email notifications on public GitHub commits
item.description: GitHub publishes an Atom feed, which means you can use any RSS reader to follow commits.

item.title: The rule of thirds can probably be ignored
item.description: Turns out that the rule of thirds for composing visuals may not be that important.

item.title: Using YubiKey for SSH access
item.description: Some pointers for setting up SSH access with YubiKey on Ubuntu 22.04.

item.title: Making a TIL section with Hugo and PaperMod
item.description: How I added a Today I Learned section to my Hugo site with the PaperMod theme.

item.title: You can't save time
item.description: Time can be spent doing different activities, but it can’t be stored and saved for later.
